utterances: The answer to that is, right now.
Hundreds of restaurants and businesses across San Francisco are displaying the black and white barcode.
This technology has already taken off in Japan, where Bulkeley says it is used everywhere, on bus stops, on public monuments, under paintings in museums.
Some enterprising young people have printed up T-shirts with personal barcodes on them that links to their MySpace or Facebook pages because they say it pays to advertise.
It's a very exciting idea.
I love the idea of it.
Absolutely love the idea of it.
Julie Ask is a personal technology analyst with Jupiter Research.
She says this visual navigation technology could take off over the next five to seven years, though for the next three years or so, she says there will be a steep learning curve for consumers.
There's a lot steps between here and what we call mass market.
You know, there are a lot of steps and there's a lot of pieces that have to come together for something like this to work.
Only certain types of cell phones with web capability, a high quality camera, and the downloadable software to access the barcodes can join the system.
This particular effort in San Francisco, she says, could falter just because there are too many hurdles in the way of using it.
Near Union Square, Ryan Bahadura(ph) of San Jose, and his friend Darren Bahaidura(ph) of Toronto, are looking for a place to eat.
They are just the demographics Scanbuy wants to capture.
Young, tech savvy, and really hungry.
This place looks tempting, actually.
Bahadura has an iPhone, so he loves the gadgets, but his phone isn't yet compatible with the barcode system.
Still, the whole idea strikes a chord with him.
I'd probably try it just because it sounds cool.
I mean, there is a need for that type of information.
But when Bahadura walks down to the barcode outside the restaurant he wants to know about, it's a different story.
Oh, you need software for it.
I don't know if I'd download the software.
That's kind of a drawback.
The makers of Scanbuy hope that in the next half year, all new cell phones will come with the software built into them.
Until them, some people will download the software and adopt the technology during this pilot run in San Francisco.
And once the software is built in, they hope, those little ubiquitous barcodes will become even more a part of our daily lives.
For NPR News, I'm David Gorn.
At midnight on August 1st, 1981, MTV blasted onto America's airwaves.
(SOUNDBITE OF MTV BROADCAST)
(SOUNDBITE OF ROCKET ENGINE)
Ladies and gentlemen, rock 'n' roll.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

MTV co-creator John Lack uttered those words before the first music video aired, Buggles' ""Video Killed the Radio Star."" Reality shows like ""The Real World"" or ""Jersey Shore"" had no part in the programming 30 years ago.
The 24-hour network was all about rock music videos, VJs and music news, and it changed the way fans related to their favorite music.
Whether it is the first time you saw Michael Jackson's ""Thriller"" or an episode of ""The Real World,"" what's your unforgettable MTV moment?
That's the phone number.
Our email address is talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation at our website.
Go to npr.org and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Matt Pinfield is the host of the indie, alternative music series ""120 Minutes,"" which first debuted on MTV in 1995.
It's back again.
And he joins us now from our bureau in New York.
Nice to have you, Matt.
How are you?
I'm good, Tony.
Thanks so much for having me on the show.
Before I ask you the first question, I want to read some of these emails.
They are pouring in here about people's remembrances of MTV.
(Reading) I remember the day it started well.
I recorded the whole day, because I didn't think that MTV would last.
This is from Darren in Wilmington.

My fondest memory of the very early days of MTV was when Madonna debuted on the MTV Music Awards in a white wedding dress singing ""Like a Virgin."" In true Madonna form, she crawled all over the stage and was somewhat vulgar.
I recall sitting with my mother, watching the show.
She was disgusted.
I was in love.
Here's another one.
The multi-continent, multistage event included amazing performances and a surprising bicoastal run by Phil Collins.
To me, it felt like Woodstock for the '80s.
So, you know, what about that, Matt?
MTV, it was - I mean, it was revolutionary.
I mean, it was.
And when it started, of course, it wasn't in as many homes as it is now, but the people that did have it were fascinated by it.
And, you know, if you were like I was, a kid at that time, you know, in my late teens, you - anybody who had it in their house, you would go over to their house and watch it for hours.
There was still the incredible novelty of seeing music videos and seeing music on television.
And in the beginning, Tony, most of the videos were actually of English and European acts, because America, at the time, had not caught on to the making of videos.
I mean, we, of course, had Don Kirshner's ""Rock Concert,"" ""Midnight Special,"" you know, ""American Bandstand"" and a bunch of different local shows back in the day.
But at that point, the reason why there was such a explosion of new wave, you know, and punk bands and boy bands from England was because they were the ones making videos at the time.
So eventually, Americans caught up, bands like ZZ Top, people like John Cougar Mellencamp, who said, you know what?
I want to have a part of this.
These bands are selling, and people are discovering them and have kind of a multimedia way of discovering them.
But getting out and meeting people is another thing altogether.
Karen started by working on Jerry's appearance.
Remember, this is a man who came of age in a Superfly era.
She made him throw out his leather jacket from the Carter administration.
She gave him a crash course in talking to modern women, and was the shoulder he cried on when he got his heart broken for the first time - at 48.
Jerry's got a lot of new choices to face and Karen says she'll continue to be there for him.
But she admits that some of his decisions are a little harder to take than others.
He loves Sade.
He loves Sade.
He loves Sade so much I hate her now.
(Soundbite of music)
For NPR News, I'm Diantha Parker.

Your love is king, crown you with my heart, your love is king, never need to part, your kisses ring, round and round and round my head, touching the very part of me...
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.

All week long, scientists have been swapping stories about our solar system, talking about the winds and sulfurous clouds on Venus, the icy volcanoes and dunes on Titan, Saturn's largest moon; and debating how the planets and their moons and rings formed - still a bit of a mystery.
All that took place at the American Astronomical Society's meeting out there in Pasadena, California.
My next guest joins us now with a few stories from that meeting.
Ron Cowen is the astronomy writer for Science News in Washington.
Welcome back to SCIENCE FRIDAY
Thanks, Ira.
And you can read about Ron's articles in sciencenews.org.
And Ron, I've got to start off with this great line that you have in that article, on that page, it's called ""It's Only a Seltzer Moon.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
Tell us what that refers to.

Okay, well, it refers to the fact that inside this moon of Saturn called Enceladus, where we think there is an ocean there, and we think there's an ocean there because we know that there are plumes of water vapor that erupt from its south polar surface.

There's a model now that says that this ocean is carbonated like Perrier inside that moon, and the carbonation, actually the bubbles in that seawater would actually help the water rise to near the surface and get through cracks in the ice and actually help fill the chambers right next to the icy surface, where these geysers actually erupt.
And without the bubbles, without the Perrier, this according to these researchers, the water really wouldn't get out.
So it's actually carbonated.
So it's like if you took the top off a seltzer bottle, it's spraying out through these volcanoes.
That's right.
That's right.
Yeah, that's what they think, yeah.
That's a great story.
Do we have any idea how all that carbonation got into the ocean in the first place?

Yeah because the core of this it is an icy moon, but the core of it is believed to be rocky, and there are carbon compounds, organic compounds believed to be in the rock and that the ocean - apparently not recently, but way but several billion years ago - soaked up some of the carbon from the rock in the middle of Enceladus, the rocky core, and got the carbonation.
As intriguing and as sort of funny as this moon is, there's a really other interesting presentation on the possibility of the building blocks of life that could be formed on Saturn's Titan.
Is that right?
Wow.
That's right.
That's Saturn's largest moon, Titan.
And Titan has this really thick atmosphere of nitrogen, methane, ethane and other organic compounds.
And people have speculated for a while, that when sunlight hits the top of this atmosphere, it can trigger all kinds of chemical reactions.
In fact, the Cassini spacecraft, which is visiting Saturn and its moons, has seen very massive, large chains of chemicals that they haven't been able to identify.
